content: In 2018, youth activism became synonymous with the gun control movement created by Florida high school students, who survived a mass shooting that killed 17 people.  Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School students made headlines for months after the February shooting in Parkland. They began by calling for gun control, and then the floodgates opened. As they organized rallies, walkouts, a voting tour, celebrity partnerships (Cc: Mark Ruffalo), and get out the vote campaigns under the banner March For Our Lives , young people across the country made their voices heard.  The young activists made it clear they care about issues like immigration rights, climate change, and LGBTQ equality, too. Young people have often been at the forefront of social movements, but in 2018 they dominated social media conversations, news coverage, forced politicians to respond, and made headlines when they voted at historic rates. An exit poll showed about 31 percent of people aged 18 to 29 voted in the midterms, up from 2014's 21 percent.  SEE ALSO: March For Our Lives protestors borrow a page from the 'Three Billboards' playbook And this is just the beginning, said Kirsten McConnell, a member of the senior leadership team for March For Our Lives, in conversation with Mashable and David Hogg, a cofounder of the activist group. The movement is also about counteracting the perception that young people don't know enough to be activists, Hogg, who graduated over the summer, added.  Instead of following tired scripts, Hogg, 18, and his fellow activists, reminded young voters before the midterm elections that voting is personal because "politicians, quite frankly, don't care about us." They talked about job opportunities after college, student debt, and school shootings.  "All those things are centered around one thing and that's voting out corrupt politicians who don't see the youth voting bloc as something that matters," Hogg, who is taking a gap year, said. The midterms marked Hogg's second time voting; McConnell, an 18-year-old Marjory Stoneman senior, voted for the first time in November.  While March for Our Lives activists traveled throughout the country to register young people to vote before the midterms, McConnell came across plenty of critics who initially didn't agree with the movement.  "We need to have that conversation with people who don’t always agree so we can learn from them, and half the time, when we really just sit and talk to them and take away all the different things the media skews about us, people can come to agree with us," McConnell said.  It's clear young people like Hogg and McConnell have been starting conversations throughout 2018, proving they can lead social good movements and make a difference. Here are 14 activists, including the Parkland teens, who have made an impact this year, in alphabetical order.  On World Children's Day, UNICEF named Millie Bobby Brown its youngest-ever Goodwill ambassador . The Stranger Things star teamed up with Orlando Bloom, Liam Neeson, and other ambassadors to encourage fans to sign the #GoBlue petition , a call to world leaders to fulfill and uphold children's rights. Throughout the year, Brown has used her massive social media platform to discuss important issues, such as girls' education , childhood cancer , and gun control .  She supported the March For Our Lives movement at the Kids’ Choice Awards with a custom denim shirt and participated in the Time's Up movement at the Brit Awards and Golden Globes .  View this post on Instagram wow. i was working today so i didn’t have time to post but thank you for my teen choice award and also thank you to every single fan out there. you are all amazing. just remember your dream is there and you just have to keep believing and trusting the process. i started with hundreds of rejections for jobs until i got that 1 that changed my life forever. thanks guys... lovin u 4L xxx A post shared by Millie Bobby Brown (@milliebobbybrown) on Aug 13, 2018 at 6:15pm PDT Edna Chavez, an activist from South Los Angeles, delivered a powerful speech at the March For Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C. She reminded Americans that gun violence has been normalized to the point that she "learned to duck from bullets" before she learned how to read. The crowd chanted "Ricardo" to remember her 14-year-old brother, who died during a shooting. Chavez has since spoken at the Teen Vogue Summit and the #WeVoteNext Summit , an event organized to educate and inspire young voters.  Chavez told Assembly (the digital publication from Malala Yousafzai's nonprofit) that the 2016 election inspired her to join a youth leadership program run by advocacy group Community Coalition , which works to transform the social and economic conditions of South Los Angeles. Chavez worked with an attorney to educate her fellow classmates about their rights. View this post on Instagram I will continue to scream, cry and fight for my people. #savetps la lucha sigue! A post shared by Edna Lizbeth Chavez (@ed.naaaa) on Jan 14, 2018 at 10:18am PST Ramon Contreras is the co-founder of Youth Over Guns , a student-led group that advocates for inclusive gun reform that protects people of color. (Youth Over Guns is now part of the nonprofit New Yorkers Against Gun Violence .) On June 2, Contreras and other activists carried a symbolic casket across the Brooklyn Bridge to demand gun control. Contreras continued his efforts throughout the summer and joined the March For Our Lives activists on their nationwide bus tour, registering young people to vote. He is the organization's national field strategist . View this post on Instagram Believe in the vision ✊🏾 A post shared by Ramon Contreras (@ramon.contreras1) on Aug 15, 2018 at 9:40am PDT Mari Copeny, who most people know as Little Miss Flint, is the chief change agent at Pack Your Back , a nonprofit that delivers school supplies to children in her hometown of Flint, Michigan, and the founder of Dear Flint Kids , a project that encourages people from around the world to send letters to kids in Flint.  She brought awareness to the water crisis in Flint when she wrote a letter to President Obama. She was only 8-years-old at the time.  She has continued advocating for her community since then. She raised funds to give hundreds of kids the opportunity to see Marvel's Black Panther and A Wrinkle in Time , and collected winter coats . Copeny spoke at Mashable's Social Good Summit and shared her five tips for becoming a young activist.  Most recently, she shut down Tomi Lahren when the conservative commentator tweeted "$5 billion spent on a wall will be the BEST $5 billion taxpayers EVER spent!" Copeny responded by saying $5 billion would be best spent on "water infrastructure upgrades and testing in schools." View this post on Instagram 🚨🚨🚨🚨ATTENTION...This is a Mari Copeny Public Service Announcement 🚨🚨🚨🚨 If you’re upset about this photo and take it as an attack on the Kardashians and miss the entire point then you are a part of the PROBLEM. Way to many people getting in their feelings over a millionaire family being “attacked” and not the fact there are dozens of city across the country with water that is poisoning its citizens...it’s not just Flint. The fact that that fact doesn’t make you mad is the issue. A post shared by Mari Copeny (@littlemissflint) on Nov 20, 2018 at 6:14am PST In 2015, Marley Dias launched the #1000BlackGirlBooks campaign to collect and distribute books featuring black girl protagonists. In 2018, she continued to promote "diversity and inclusion" at several speaking events and throughout her book tour promoting Marley Dias Gets It Done: And So Can You! The book explores activism, social justice, volunteerism, and includes an introduction by Wrinkle in Time director Ava DuVernay.  Dias is also the president of SuperGirls Society, a leadership program for black girls. The program is part of the GrassRoots Community Foundation, "a public health and social action organization." She participated in the organization's Green Ribbon Week , a mental health campaign that aims to support young people.  View this post on Instagram I partnered with @callitspring and @metowe for  #WEcallitchange Together, they have launched a limited-edition line of socially conscious accessories, each of which gives back to three key impact pillars in developing communities in Kenya - education, clean water, and opportunity🌍Check out more info in my bio! A post shared by Marley Dias (@iammarleydias) on Apr 3, 2018 at 4:39pm PDT Katie Eder is one of the founding members of the Future Coalition, a network of over 25 youth-led organizations. Together, they organized Walkout to Vote, the nationwide school walkout that encouraged students, no matter their age, to march to the polls on Election Day. Eder is also the executive director of 50 Miles More , a youth-led organization that advocates for gun reform. Eder and other high school students marched from Madison, Wisconsin, to Rep. Paul Ryan's hometown of Janesville, to demand gun control and stand in solidarity with the survivors of the Parkland mass shooting.  View this post on Instagram Four days until #MarchForOurLives and #50More. Make sure you have marching plans! @50milesmore A post shared by Katie Eder (@katie.eder) on Mar 20, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT In November, Jazz Jennings filmed the short movie Denim , which aims to raise awareness about the discrimination trans youth experience in schools. Whether it's through her YouTube videos , her reality television series, or her Blindfold Magazine mini-documentary , Jennings has consistently been open about her experiences as a trans teen activist. She also teamed up with Dove's Self-Esteem project and television producer Shonda Rhimes to launch Girl Collective , "a sisterhood that builds body confidence and challenges beauty stereotypes for all women and girls." View this post on Instagram Today I voted! If you are an eligible voter and haven’t voted yet, please do it now!❤️ Your voice matters and can truly make a difference. Let’s do this!! #WontBeErased A post shared by Jazz Jennings (@jazzjennings_) on Nov 1, 2018 at 1:15pm PDT Jamie Margolin is the founder of Zero Hour , a youth-led movement working to combat climate change, with a focus on marginalized voices. On July 21, she and other teen activists marched on Washington, D.C., to demand leaders enact long-term climate solutions. Margolin and 12 other young people sued her home state of Washington. After the case was dismissed, Margolin wrote an op-ed , explaining how the government's failure to address climate change violates her rights.  View this post on Instagram Had a great time last night speaking at the LA premiere of @natgeochannel ’s @paristopittsburgh ! The movie does a great job of highlighting the voices of people on the frontlines of the climate crisis, and I’m proud to have @thisiszerohour ‘s #YouthClimateMarch be the way the doccumentary ends on that last line of hope. The movie ends with us the #ThisIsZeroHour youth chanting “Whose future? Our future!” I am proud to be working alongside the amazing @thisiszerohour team to change the world, and we have some exciting new actions up our sleeves to be announced in the new year!#24hoursofreality #paristopittsburgh #Bloomberg #NatGeo #ThisIsZeroHour A post shared by Jamie Margolin (@jamie_s_margolin) on Dec 4, 2018 at 8:35am PST Xiuhtezcatl Martinez is the youth director at Earth Guardians, a group of young activists, artists and musicians that works to counteract climate change. Along with 21 young people , the organization is suing the federal government for its failure to address climate change (This lawsuit is separate from Margolin's). In addition to being a climate activist, Martinez is also a hip-hop artist. In 2018, he released his first full-length hip-hop album, Break Free , which covers climate change and the marginalization of indigenous people, according to i-D .  View this post on Instagram The world has to fall apart to be more than what it is. . And I guess that’s what this is. The storms and the fires. The disappearing ice and rising tides. The people suffering. The monsters being put in power. An old broken world falling away. Making room for the vision my generation has of the world we’ll build. . It’s hard to believe things will get better when the lights burn this low. I struggle with that. We have to have hope in our power to push the scales in the right direction. Do what you can and a little more. Fight for your people and those that look nothing like you. Defend clean water. Protect your heart. Resist injustice. Take time to love yo momma. . Its never been easy. And the struggle will prolly never be. I’m tryin. Fire in the eyes of this young boy. Of a world burning and a generation on fire with passion. Thank you for having my back. Como familia. That’s how we’ll overcome 💧🌊 . Foto: @rickyrozay #breakfree A post shared by Xiuhtezcatl (@xiuhtezcatl) on Oct 11, 2018 at 11:29am PDT Desmond Napoles, also known as Desmond is Amazing, is an LGBTQ activist and drag artist. A video of him wearing a rainbow tutu at the NYC Pride Parade went viral in 2015. Since then, he launched the first-ever drag house for kids, which is currently under works, according to his website . On social media, he stands up against bullying and advocates for LGBTQ youth. His main message to his thousands of followers is "be yourself, always." In September, Napoles participated in Change the Ref's back-to-school fashion show , in which models wore gas masks and bullet-proof vests to raise awareness about gun violence. Change the Ref was founded by Manuel and Patricia Oliver, whose son Joaquin was killed during the Parkland school shooting. The nonprofit organization empowers young people to get involved in politics and help end gun violence.  View this post on Instagram @changetheref Back to School fashion show/protest to show how ridiculous our level of gun violence is with back to school fashions reflecting our culture. Never again. @gaysagainstgunsny Photos 1-4: @desmondisamazing Photos 5-10: @donnaaceto . . . #changetheref #altdrag #babydrag #beauty #boysinmakeup #brooklyndrag #clubkid #clubkids #drag #dragart #dragartist #dragkid #dragkids #draglife #dragqueen #dragqueer #dragsuperstar #influencer #klubkids #love #myartistcommunity #mua #nonbinary #nycdrag #punky #queerartist #queermodel . #desmondisamazing #beyourselfalways #amazies . booking: @pegmgmt A post shared by Desmond is Amazing (@desmondisamazing) on Sep 12, 2018 at 5:07pm PDT Cameron Kasky, Jaclyn Corin, David Hogg, Emma González, Alex Wind, and many other students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, proved that young people can influence elections. Following the mass shooting at their school in February, González was one of the first voices to make headlines when she delivered her now-famous "We Call B.S." speech. Since then, González and her fellow Parkland classmates have been working hard to demand gun control. They organized a nationwide march in the spring and a bus tour in preparation for the midterm elections.  Jammal Lemy, the March for Our Lives creative director, designed flag T-shirts with QR codes that you saw throughout the summer during the March For Our Lives national bus tour. When you scan the QR code, the shirt takes you to a voter registration page (genius!). Elle magazine reported that as of August 2018, about 10,000 people used the shirts to register. The students also published the book Glimmer of Hope: How Tragedy Sparked a Movement , which supports the March For Our Lives Action Fund .  (Kasky was photographed alongside March For Our Lives activists as part of the 2018 TIME 100 Most Influential People list , but in September, he announced he was leaving the organization.) View this post on Instagram ‪What an honor to be a part of #Time100 alongside so many influential people. Thank you @BarackObama for your incredibly kind words. This is not a moment, this is a movement. #MarchForOurLives A post shared by March For Our Lives (@marchforourlives) on Apr 19, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT Storm Reid, best known for her starring role in A Wrinkle in Time , advocated for girls' education , bullying prevention , and other important causes on social media. Reid also launched Bamazing , an initiative to promote self-love and encourage girls to believe in themselves. She designed so-called "You Are" shirts that say "you=extraordinary" and "you= inspiring," along with other accolades. Celebrities, including Yara Shahidi ( Black-ish) and Zendaya ( The Greatest Showman ), have been wearing the shirts. Sales from the tees benefit LadyLike Foundation , an organization that offers workshops and classes to help girls in underprivileged communities reach their full potential, and Array Alliance , an independent film festival founded by Ava DuVernay.  View this post on Instagram God please help me to keep dreaming of ways to make a positive impact on young girls. ✨I’m super excited to soon launch an initiative that I pray will make a difference in someone else’s life. Putting my words into action✨ Bamazing aims to empower young girls by helping them discover and nurture their inner light through the encouragement of positive declarations of self. Our goal is to put emphasis on the uplifting qualities within each of us that will lead to more self-love and empathy for others. Promoting a healthy self-esteem early on, will give the youth a head start in molding a healthier and more tolerant future. Everything is possible when you know and you are confident about all the things you can be. Bbrave, Bkind, Blove, Bbold, #Bamazing! A post shared by Storm Reid 💥💫 (@stormreid) on Sep 1, 2018 at 2:17pm PDT In preparation for the midterm elections, Shahidi teamed up with NowThis and launched Eighteen x 18 , an initiative to encourage young people to register to vote . In September, she hosted the #WeVoteNext Summit in Los Angeles. Celebrities like Lauren Jauregui and Laverne Cox, as well as activists David Hogg and Nadya Okamoto , of PERIOD , a nonprofit that provides menstrual supplies to people in need, attended to support the cause. In partnership with Aerie, Shahidi designed a sweatshirt to raise funds for the Innocence Project , which helps free innocent people from prison.  I’m so proud to introduce my very own @Aerie x Yara City Sweatshirt! 100% of sales will be donated to @innocence , a cause close to my heart. You can show your support & get yours at /JNssbvarz6 #Thrive ✨ pic.twitter.com/o2PXHJUdzh — Yara shahidi (@YaraShahidi) March 8, 2018 In a Time essay , actress Josie Totah came out as a transgender female. The actress previously starred in Disney Channel's Jessie and Mindy Kaling's series Champions. On social media, she advocates for LGBTQ rights and other important causes. For example, she encouraged her followers to join the Trevor Project, which provides crisis and suicide prevention services for LGBTQ youth, in its fight to end conversion therapy . The Human Rights Campaign this year awarded Totah the HRC Visibility Award , which recognizes people who use their talent and platform to support LGBTQ people.  View this post on Instagram For so long I’ve been trying to hide who I was by pretending I’m someone I’m not. And I did it in fear. In fear that I wouldn’t be accepted or loved. I tried so hard to become a person that I knew I never was. But I’m realizing I can’t fake it forever. I know now more than ever I’m ready to take the step to becoming myself. I am Transgender and this is my story. A post shared by josie (@josietotah) on Aug 20, 2018 at 10:01am PDT Correction Dec. 24, 2018, 10:04 a.m. PST A previous version of this post incorrectly noted the name of the shirts Storm Reid has been selling to promote self-love. They are called "You Are" shirts not bamazing, which is the name of her initiative.
title_html: The youth activists who proved critics wrong in 2018

Social Good

Like Follow

The youth activists who proved critics wrong in 2018

Share
Tweet
What's This?
By Victoria Rodriguez2018-12-18 10:30:00 UTC

In 2018, youth activism became synonymous with the gun control movement created by Florida high school students, who survived a mass shooting that killed 17 people. 

Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School students made headlines for months after the February shooting in Parkland. They began by calling for gun control, and then the floodgates opened. As they organized rallies, walkouts, a voting tour, celebrity partnerships (Cc: Mark Ruffalo), and get out the vote campaigns under the banner March For Our Lives, young people across the country made their voices heard. 

The young activists made it clear they care about issues like immigration rights, climate change, and LGBTQ equality, too. Young people have often been at the forefront of social movements, but in 2018 they dominated social media conversations, news coverage, forced politicians to respond, and made headlines when they voted at historic rates. An exit poll showed about 31 percent of people aged 18 to 29 voted in the midterms, up from 2014's 21 percent. 

SEE ALSO: March For Our Lives protestors borrow a page from the 'Three Billboards' playbook

And this is just the beginning, said Kirsten McConnell, a member of the senior leadership team for March For Our Lives, in conversation with Mashable and David Hogg, a cofounder of the activist group.

The movement is also about counteracting the perception that young people don't know enough to be activists, Hogg, who graduated over the summer, added. 

Instead of following tired scripts, Hogg, 18, and his fellow activists, reminded young voters before the midterm elections that voting is personal because "politicians, quite frankly, don't care about us." They talked about job opportunities after college, student debt, and school shootings. 

"All those things are centered around one thing and that's voting out corrupt politicians who don't see the youth voting bloc as something that matters," Hogg, who is taking a gap year, said. The midterms marked Hogg's second time voting; McConnell, an 18-year-old Marjory Stoneman senior, voted for the first time in November. 

While March for Our Lives activists traveled throughout the country to register young people to vote before the midterms, McConnell came across plenty of critics who initially didn't agree with the movement. 

"We need to have that conversation with people who don’t always agree so we can learn from them, and half the time, when we really just sit and talk to them and take away all the different things the media skews about us, people can come to agree with us," McConnell said. 

It's clear young people like Hogg and McConnell have been starting conversations throughout 2018, proving they can lead social good movements and make a difference. Here are 14 activists, including the Parkland teens, who have made an impact this year, in alphabetical order. 

1. Millie Bobby Brown, 14

On World Children's Day, UNICEF named Millie Bobby Brown its youngest-ever Goodwill ambassador. The Stranger Things star teamed up with Orlando Bloom, Liam Neeson, and other ambassadors to encourage fans to sign the #GoBlue petition, a call to world leaders to fulfill and uphold children's rights. Throughout the year, Brown has used her massive social media platform to discuss important issues, such as girls' education, childhood cancer, and gun control. 

She supported the March For Our Lives movement at the Kids’ Choice Awards with a custom denim shirt and participated in the Time's Up movement at the Brit Awards and Golden Globes. 

View this post on Instagram

wow. i was working today so i didn’t have time to post but thank you for my teen choice award and also thank you to every single fan out there. you are all amazing. just remember your dream is there and you just have to keep believing and trusting the process. i started with hundreds of rejections for jobs until i got that 1 that changed my life forever. thanks guys... lovin u 4L xxx

A post shared by Millie Bobby Brown (@milliebobbybrown) on Aug 13, 2018 at 6:15pm PDT


2. Edna Chavez, 18

Edna Chavez, an activist from South Los Angeles, delivered a powerful speech at the March For Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C. She reminded Americans that gun violence has been normalized to the point that she "learned to duck from bullets" before she learned how to read. The crowd chanted "Ricardo" to remember her 14-year-old brother, who died during a shooting. Chavez has since spoken at the Teen Vogue Summit and the #WeVoteNext Summit, an event organized to educate and inspire young voters. 

Chavez told Assembly (the digital publication from Malala Yousafzai's nonprofit) that the 2016 election inspired her to join a youth leadership program run by advocacy group Community Coalition, which works to transform the social and economic conditions of South Los Angeles. Chavez worked with an attorney to educate her fellow classmates about their rights.

View this post on Instagram

I will continue to scream, cry and fight for my people. #savetps la lucha sigue!

A post shared by Edna Lizbeth Chavez (@ed.naaaa) on Jan 14, 2018 at 10:18am PST


3. Ramon Contreras, 19

Ramon Contreras is the co-founder of Youth Over Guns, a student-led group that advocates for inclusive gun reform that protects people of color. (Youth Over Guns is now part of the nonprofit New Yorkers Against Gun Violence.) On June 2, Contreras and other activists carried a symbolic casket across the Brooklyn Bridge to demand gun control. Contreras continued his efforts throughout the summer and joined the March For Our Lives activists on their nationwide bus tour, registering young people to vote. He is the organization's national field strategist.

View this post on Instagram

Believe in the vision ✊🏾

A post shared by Ramon Contreras (@ramon.contreras1) on Aug 15, 2018 at 9:40am PDT


4. Mari Copeny, 11

Mari Copeny, who most people know as Little Miss Flint, is the chief change agent at Pack Your Back, a nonprofit that delivers school supplies to children in her hometown of Flint, Michigan, and the founder of Dear Flint Kids, a project that encourages people from around the world to send letters to kids in Flint. 

She brought awareness to the water crisis in Flint when she wrote a letter to President Obama. She was only 8-years-old at the time. 

She has continued advocating for her community since then. She raised funds to give hundreds of kids the opportunity to see Marvel's Black Panther and A Wrinkle in Time, and collected winter coats. Copeny spoke at Mashable's Social Good Summit and shared her five tips for becoming a young activist. 

Most recently, she shut down Tomi Lahren when the conservative commentator tweeted "$5 billion spent on a wall will be the BEST $5 billion taxpayers EVER spent!" Copeny responded by saying $5 billion would be best spent on "water infrastructure upgrades and testing in schools."

View this post on Instagram

🚨🚨🚨🚨ATTENTION...This is a Mari Copeny Public Service Announcement 🚨🚨🚨🚨 If you’re upset about this photo and take it as an attack on the Kardashians and miss the entire point then you are a part of the PROBLEM. Way to many people getting in their feelings over a millionaire family being “attacked” and not the fact there are dozens of city across the country with water that is poisoning its citizens...it’s not just Flint. The fact that that fact doesn’t make you mad is the issue.

A post shared by Mari Copeny (@littlemissflint) on Nov 20, 2018 at 6:14am PST

5. Marley Dias, 13

In 2015, Marley Dias launched the #1000BlackGirlBooks campaign to collect and distribute books featuring black girl protagonists. In 2018, she continued to promote "diversity and inclusion" at several speaking events and throughout her book tour promoting Marley Dias Gets It Done: And So Can You! The book explores activism, social justice, volunteerism, and includes an introduction by Wrinkle in Time director Ava DuVernay. 

Dias is also the president of SuperGirls Society, a leadership program for black girls. The program is part of the GrassRoots Community Foundation, "a public health and social action organization." She participated in the organization's Green Ribbon Week, a mental health campaign that aims to support young people. 

View this post on Instagram

I partnered with @callitspring and @metowe for  #WEcallitchange Together, they have launched a limited-edition line of socially conscious accessories, each of which gives back to three key impact pillars in developing communities in Kenya - education, clean water, and opportunity🌍Check out more info in my bio!

A post shared by Marley Dias (@iammarleydias) on Apr 3, 2018 at 4:39pm PDT


6. Katie Eder, 19

Katie Eder is one of the founding members of the Future Coalition, a network of over 25 youth-led organizations. Together, they organized Walkout to Vote, the nationwide school walkout that encouraged students, no matter their age, to march to the polls on Election Day. Eder is also the executive director of 50 Miles More, a youth-led organization that advocates for gun reform. Eder and other high school students marched from Madison, Wisconsin, to Rep. Paul Ryan's hometown of Janesville, to demand gun control and stand in solidarity with the survivors of the Parkland mass shooting. 

View this post on Instagram

Four days until #MarchForOurLives and #50More. Make sure you have marching plans! @50milesmore

A post shared by Katie Eder (@katie.eder) on Mar 20, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT


7. Jazz Jennings, 18

In November, Jazz Jennings filmed the short movie Denim, which aims to raise awareness about the discrimination trans youth experience in schools. Whether it's through her YouTube videos, her reality television series, or her Blindfold Magazine mini-documentary, Jennings has consistently been open about her experiences as a trans teen activist. She also teamed up with Dove's Self-Esteem project and television producer Shonda Rhimes to launch Girl Collective, "a sisterhood that builds body confidence and challenges beauty stereotypes for all women and girls."

View this post on Instagram

Today I voted! If you are an eligible voter and haven’t voted yet, please do it now!❤️ Your voice matters and can truly make a difference. Let’s do this!! #WontBeErased

A post shared by Jazz Jennings (@jazzjennings_) on Nov 1, 2018 at 1:15pm PDT


8. Jamie Margolin, 17

Jamie Margolin is the founder of Zero Hour, a youth-led movement working to combat climate change, with a focus on marginalized voices. On July 21, she and other teen activists marched on Washington, D.C., to demand leaders enact long-term climate solutions. Margolin and 12 other young people sued her home state of Washington. After the case was dismissed, Margolin wrote an op-ed, explaining how the government's failure to address climate change violates her rights. 

View this post on Instagram

Had a great time last night speaking at the LA premiere of @natgeochannel ’s @paristopittsburgh ! The movie does a great job of highlighting the voices of people on the frontlines of the climate crisis, and I’m proud to have @thisiszerohour ‘s #YouthClimateMarch be the way the doccumentary ends on that last line of hope. The movie ends with us the #ThisIsZeroHour youth chanting “Whose future? Our future!” I am proud to be working alongside the amazing @thisiszerohour team to change the world, and we have some exciting new actions up our sleeves to be announced in the new year!#24hoursofreality #paristopittsburgh #Bloomberg #NatGeo #ThisIsZeroHour

A post shared by Jamie Margolin (@jamie_s_margolin) on Dec 4, 2018 at 8:35am PST

9. Xiuhtezcatl Martinez, 18

Xiuhtezcatl Martinez is the youth director at Earth Guardians, a group of young activists, artists and musicians that works to counteract climate change. Along with 21 young people, the organization is suing the federal government for its failure to address climate change (This lawsuit is separate from Margolin's). In addition to being a climate activist, Martinez is also a hip-hop artist. In 2018, he released his first full-length hip-hop album, Break Free, which covers climate change and the marginalization of indigenous people, according to i-D. 

View this post on Instagram

The world has to fall apart to be more than what it is. . And I guess that’s what this is. The storms and the fires. The disappearing ice and rising tides. The people suffering. The monsters being put in power. An old broken world falling away. Making room for the vision my generation has of the world we’ll build. . It’s hard to believe things will get better when the lights burn this low. I struggle with that. We have to have hope in our power to push the scales in the right direction. Do what you can and a little more. Fight for your people and those that look nothing like you. Defend clean water. Protect your heart. Resist injustice. Take time to love yo momma. . Its never been easy. And the struggle will prolly never be. I’m tryin. Fire in the eyes of this young boy. Of a world burning and a generation on fire with passion. Thank you for having my back. Como familia. That’s how we’ll overcome 💧🌊 . Foto: @rickyrozay #breakfree

A post shared by Xiuhtezcatl (@xiuhtezcatl) on Oct 11, 2018 at 11:29am PDT


10. Desmond Napoles, 11

Desmond Napoles, also known as Desmond is Amazing, is an LGBTQ activist and drag artist. A video of him wearing a rainbow tutu at the NYC Pride Parade went viral in 2015. Since then, he launched the first-ever drag house for kids, which is currently under works, according to his website. On social media, he stands up against bullying and advocates for LGBTQ youth. His main message to his thousands of followers is "be yourself, always."

In September, Napoles participated in Change the Ref's back-to-school fashion show, in which models wore gas masks and bullet-proof vests to raise awareness about gun violence. Change the Ref was founded by Manuel and Patricia Oliver, whose son Joaquin was killed during the Parkland school shooting. The nonprofit organization empowers young people to get involved in politics and help end gun violence. 

View this post on Instagram

@changetheref Back to School fashion show/protest to show how ridiculous our level of gun violence is with back to school fashions reflecting our culture. Never again. @gaysagainstgunsny Photos 1-4: @desmondisamazing Photos 5-10: @donnaaceto . . . #changetheref #altdrag #babydrag #beauty #boysinmakeup #brooklyndrag #clubkid #clubkids #drag #dragart #dragartist #dragkid #dragkids #draglife #dragqueen #dragqueer #dragsuperstar #influencer #klubkids #love #myartistcommunity #mua #nonbinary #nycdrag #punky #queerartist #queermodel . #desmondisamazing #beyourselfalways #amazies . booking: @pegmgmt

A post shared by Desmond is Amazing (@desmondisamazing) on Sep 12, 2018 at 5:07pm PDT

11. Parkland students, 17-19

Cameron Kasky, Jaclyn Corin, David Hogg, Emma González, Alex Wind, and many other students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, proved that young people can influence elections. Following the mass shooting at their school in February, González was one of the first voices to make headlines when she delivered her now-famous "We Call B.S." speech.

Since then, González and her fellow Parkland classmates have been working hard to demand gun control. They organized a nationwide march in the spring and a bus tour in preparation for the midterm elections. 

Jammal Lemy, the March for Our Lives creative director, designed flag T-shirts with QR codes that you saw throughout the summer during the March For Our Lives national bus tour. When you scan the QR code, the shirt takes you to a voter registration page (genius!). Elle magazine reported that as of August 2018, about 10,000 people used the shirts to register.

The students also published the book Glimmer of Hope: How Tragedy Sparked a Movement, which supports the March For Our Lives Action Fund. 

(Kasky was photographed alongside March For Our Lives activists as part of the 2018 TIME 100 Most Influential People list, but in September, he announced he was leaving the organization.)

View this post on Instagram

‪What an honor to be a part of #Time100 alongside so many influential people. Thank you @BarackObama for your incredibly kind words. This is not a moment, this is a movement. #MarchForOurLives

A post shared by March For Our Lives (@marchforourlives) on Apr 19, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT


12. Storm Reid, 15

Storm Reid, best known for her starring role in A Wrinkle in Time, advocated for girls' education, bullying prevention, and other important causes on social media. Reid also launched Bamazing, an initiative to promote self-love and encourage girls to believe in themselves. She designed so-called "You Are" shirts that say "you=extraordinary" and "you= inspiring," along with other accolades. Celebrities, including Yara Shahidi (Black-ish) and Zendaya (The Greatest Showman), have been wearing the shirts. Sales from the tees benefit LadyLike Foundation, an organization that offers workshops and classes to help girls in underprivileged communities reach their full potential, and Array Alliance, an independent film festival founded by Ava DuVernay. 

View this post on Instagram

God please help me to keep dreaming of ways to make a positive impact on young girls. ✨I’m super excited to soon launch an initiative that I pray will make a difference in someone else’s life. Putting my words into action✨ Bamazing aims to empower young girls by helping them discover and nurture their inner light through the encouragement of positive declarations of self. Our goal is to put emphasis on the uplifting qualities within each of us that will lead to more self-love and empathy for others. Promoting a healthy self-esteem early on, will give the youth a head start in molding a healthier and more tolerant future. Everything is possible when you know and you are confident about all the things you can be. Bbrave, Bkind, Blove, Bbold, #Bamazing!

A post shared by Storm Reid 💥💫 (@stormreid) on Sep 1, 2018 at 2:17pm PDT


13. Yara Shahidi, 18

In preparation for the midterm elections, Shahidi teamed up with NowThis and launched Eighteen x 18, an initiative to encourage young people to register to vote. In September, she hosted the #WeVoteNext Summit in Los Angeles. Celebrities like Lauren Jauregui and Laverne Cox, as well as activists David Hogg and Nadya Okamoto, of PERIOD, a nonprofit that provides menstrual supplies to people in need, attended to support the cause. In partnership with Aerie, Shahidi designed a sweatshirt to raise funds for the Innocence Project, which helps free innocent people from prison. 

I’m so proud to introduce my very own @Aerie x Yara City Sweatshirt! 100% of sales will be donated to @innocence, a cause close to my heart. You can show your support & get yours at https://t.co/JNssbvarz6 #Thrive ✨ pic.twitter.com/o2PXHJUdzh

— Yara shahidi (@YaraShahidi) March 8, 2018

14. Josie Totah, 17

In a Time essay, actress Josie Totah came out as a transgender female. The actress previously starred in Disney Channel's Jessie and Mindy Kaling's series Champions. On social media, she advocates for LGBTQ rights and other important causes. For example, she encouraged her followers to join the Trevor Project, which provides crisis and suicide prevention services for LGBTQ youth, in its fight to end conversion therapy. The Human Rights Campaign this year awarded Totah the HRC Visibility Award, which recognizes people who use their talent and platform to support LGBTQ people. 

View this post on Instagram

For so long I’ve been trying to hide who I was by pretending I’m someone I’m not. And I did it in fear. In fear that I wouldn’t be accepted or loved. I tried so hard to become a person that I knew I never was. But I’m realizing I can’t fake it forever. I know now more than ever I’m ready to take the step to becoming myself. I am Transgender and this is my story.

A post shared by josie (@josietotah) on Aug 20, 2018 at 10:01am PDT

Correction Dec. 24, 2018, 10:04 a.m. PST A previous version of this post incorrectly noted the name of the shirts Storm Reid has been selling to promote self-love. They are called "You Are" shirts not bamazing, which is the name of her initiative.

WATCH: Ringo Starr, Yoko Ono, and Jeff Bridges 'come together' to promote student activism

Topics: Activism, activist, Activists, End of Year 2018, Politics, Social Good, teens

title: The youth activists who proved critics wrong in 2018
content_html:
In 2018, youth activism became synonymous with the gun control movement created by Florida high school students, who survived a mass shooting that killed 17 people. 

Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School students made headlines for months after the February shooting in Parkland. They began by calling for gun control, and then the floodgates opened. As they organized rallies, walkouts, a voting tour, celebrity partnerships (Cc: Mark Ruffalo), and get out the vote campaigns under the banner March For Our Lives, young people across the country made their voices heard. 

The young activists made it clear they care about issues like immigration rights, climate change, and LGBTQ equality, too. Young people have often been at the forefront of social movements, but in 2018 they dominated social media conversations, news coverage, forced politicians to respond, and made headlines when they voted at historic rates. An exit poll showed about 31 percent of people aged 18 to 29 voted in the midterms, up from 2014's 21 percent. 

SEE ALSO: March For Our Lives protestors borrow a page from the 'Three Billboards' playbook

And this is just the beginning, said Kirsten McConnell, a member of the senior leadership team for March For Our Lives, in conversation with Mashable and David Hogg, a cofounder of the activist group.

The movement is also about counteracting the perception that young people don't know enough to be activists, Hogg, who graduated over the summer, added. 

Instead of following tired scripts, Hogg, 18, and his fellow activists, reminded young voters before the midterm elections that voting is personal because "politicians, quite frankly, don't care about us." They talked about job opportunities after college, student debt, and school shootings. 

"All those things are centered around one thing and that's voting out corrupt politicians who don't see the youth voting bloc as something that matters," Hogg, who is taking a gap year, said. The midterms marked Hogg's second time voting; McConnell, an 18-year-old Marjory Stoneman senior, voted for the first time in November. 

While March for Our Lives activists traveled throughout the country to register young people to vote before the midterms, McConnell came across plenty of critics who initially didn't agree with the movement. 

"We need to have that conversation with people who don’t always agree so we can learn from them, and half the time, when we really just sit and talk to them and take away all the different things the media skews about us, people can come to agree with us," McConnell said. 

It's clear young people like Hogg and McConnell have been starting conversations throughout 2018, proving they can lead social good movements and make a difference. Here are 14 activists, including the Parkland teens, who have made an impact this year, in alphabetical order. 

On World Children's Day, UNICEF named Millie Bobby Brown its youngest-ever Goodwill ambassador. The Stranger Things star teamed up with Orlando Bloom, Liam Neeson, and other ambassadors to encourage fans to sign the #GoBlue petition, a call to world leaders to fulfill and uphold children's rights. Throughout the year, Brown has used her massive social media platform to discuss important issues, such as girls' education, childhood cancer, and gun control. 

She supported the March For Our Lives movement at the Kids’ Choice Awards with a custom denim shirt and participated in the Time's Up movement at the Brit Awards and Golden Globes. 

View this post on Instagram

wow. i was working today so i didn’t have time to post but thank you for my teen choice award and also thank you to every single fan out there. you are all amazing. just remember your dream is there and you just have to keep believing and trusting the process. i started with hundreds of rejections for jobs until i got that 1 that changed my life forever. thanks guys... lovin u 4L xxx

A post shared by Millie Bobby Brown (@milliebobbybrown) on Aug 13, 2018 at 6:15pm PDT

Edna Chavez, an activist from South Los Angeles, delivered a powerful speech at the March For Our Lives rally in Washington, D.C. She reminded Americans that gun violence has been normalized to the point that she "learned to duck from bullets" before she learned how to read. The crowd chanted "Ricardo" to remember her 14-year-old brother, who died during a shooting. Chavez has since spoken at the Teen Vogue Summit and the #WeVoteNext Summit, an event organized to educate and inspire young voters. 

Chavez told Assembly (the digital publication from Malala Yousafzai's nonprofit) that the 2016 election inspired her to join a youth leadership program run by advocacy group Community Coalition, which works to transform the social and economic conditions of South Los Angeles. Chavez worked with an attorney to educate her fellow classmates about their rights.

View this post on Instagram

I will continue to scream, cry and fight for my people. #savetps la lucha sigue!

A post shared by Edna Lizbeth Chavez (@ed.naaaa) on Jan 14, 2018 at 10:18am PST

Ramon Contreras is the co-founder of Youth Over Guns, a student-led group that advocates for inclusive gun reform that protects people of color. (Youth Over Guns is now part of the nonprofit New Yorkers Against Gun Violence.) On June 2, Contreras and other activists carried a symbolic casket across the Brooklyn Bridge to demand gun control. Contreras continued his efforts throughout the summer and joined the March For Our Lives activists on their nationwide bus tour, registering young people to vote. He is the organization's national field strategist.

View this post on Instagram

Believe in the vision ✊🏾

A post shared by Ramon Contreras (@ramon.contreras1) on Aug 15, 2018 at 9:40am PDT

Mari Copeny, who most people know as Little Miss Flint, is the chief change agent at Pack Your Back, a nonprofit that delivers school supplies to children in her hometown of Flint, Michigan, and the founder of Dear Flint Kids, a project that encourages people from around the world to send letters to kids in Flint. 

She brought awareness to the water crisis in Flint when she wrote a letter to President Obama. She was only 8-years-old at the time. 

She has continued advocating for her community since then. She raised funds to give hundreds of kids the opportunity to see Marvel's Black Panther and A Wrinkle in Time, and collected winter coats. Copeny spoke at Mashable's Social Good Summit and shared her five tips for becoming a young activist. 

Most recently, she shut down Tomi Lahren when the conservative commentator tweeted "$5 billion spent on a wall will be the BEST $5 billion taxpayers EVER spent!" Copeny responded by saying $5 billion would be best spent on "water infrastructure upgrades and testing in schools."

View this post on Instagram

🚨🚨🚨🚨ATTENTION...This is a Mari Copeny Public Service Announcement 🚨🚨🚨🚨 If you’re upset about this photo and take it as an attack on the Kardashians and miss the entire point then you are a part of the PROBLEM. Way to many people getting in their feelings over a millionaire family being “attacked” and not the fact there are dozens of city across the country with water that is poisoning its citizens...it’s not just Flint. The fact that that fact doesn’t make you mad is the issue.

A post shared by Mari Copeny (@littlemissflint) on Nov 20, 2018 at 6:14am PST

In 2015, Marley Dias launched the #1000BlackGirlBooks campaign to collect and distribute books featuring black girl protagonists. In 2018, she continued to promote "diversity and inclusion" at several speaking events and throughout her book tour promoting Marley Dias Gets It Done: And So Can You! The book explores activism, social justice, volunteerism, and includes an introduction by Wrinkle in Time director Ava DuVernay. 

Dias is also the president of SuperGirls Society, a leadership program for black girls. The program is part of the GrassRoots Community Foundation, "a public health and social action organization." She participated in the organization's Green Ribbon Week, a mental health campaign that aims to support young people. 

View this post on Instagram

I partnered with @callitspring and @metowe for  #WEcallitchange Together, they have launched a limited-edition line of socially conscious accessories, each of which gives back to three key impact pillars in developing communities in Kenya - education, clean water, and opportunity🌍Check out more info in my bio!

A post shared by Marley Dias (@iammarleydias) on Apr 3, 2018 at 4:39pm PDT

Katie Eder is one of the founding members of the Future Coalition, a network of over 25 youth-led organizations. Together, they organized Walkout to Vote, the nationwide school walkout that encouraged students, no matter their age, to march to the polls on Election Day. Eder is also the executive director of 50 Miles More, a youth-led organization that advocates for gun reform. Eder and other high school students marched from Madison, Wisconsin, to Rep. Paul Ryan's hometown of Janesville, to demand gun control and stand in solidarity with the survivors of the Parkland mass shooting. 

View this post on Instagram

Four days until #MarchForOurLives and #50More. Make sure you have marching plans! @50milesmore

A post shared by Katie Eder (@katie.eder) on Mar 20, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT

In November, Jazz Jennings filmed the short movie Denim, which aims to raise awareness about the discrimination trans youth experience in schools. Whether it's through her YouTube videos, her reality television series, or her Blindfold Magazine mini-documentary, Jennings has consistently been open about her experiences as a trans teen activist. She also teamed up with Dove's Self-Esteem project and television producer Shonda Rhimes to launch Girl Collective, "a sisterhood that builds body confidence and challenges beauty stereotypes for all women and girls."

View this post on Instagram

Today I voted! If you are an eligible voter and haven’t voted yet, please do it now!❤️ Your voice matters and can truly make a difference. Let’s do this!! #WontBeErased

A post shared by Jazz Jennings (@jazzjennings_) on Nov 1, 2018 at 1:15pm PDT

Jamie Margolin is the founder of Zero Hour, a youth-led movement working to combat climate change, with a focus on marginalized voices. On July 21, she and other teen activists marched on Washington, D.C., to demand leaders enact long-term climate solutions. Margolin and 12 other young people sued her home state of Washington. After the case was dismissed, Margolin wrote an op-ed, explaining how the government's failure to address climate change violates her rights. 

View this post on Instagram

Had a great time last night speaking at the LA premiere of @natgeochannel ’s @paristopittsburgh ! The movie does a great job of highlighting the voices of people on the frontlines of the climate crisis, and I’m proud to have @thisiszerohour ‘s #YouthClimateMarch be the way the doccumentary ends on that last line of hope. The movie ends with us the #ThisIsZeroHour youth chanting “Whose future? Our future!” I am proud to be working alongside the amazing @thisiszerohour team to change the world, and we have some exciting new actions up our sleeves to be announced in the new year!#24hoursofreality #paristopittsburgh #Bloomberg #NatGeo #ThisIsZeroHour

A post shared by Jamie Margolin (@jamie_s_margolin) on Dec 4, 2018 at 8:35am PST

Xiuhtezcatl Martinez is the youth director at Earth Guardians, a group of young activists, artists and musicians that works to counteract climate change. Along with 21 young people, the organization is suing the federal government for its failure to address climate change (This lawsuit is separate from Margolin's). In addition to being a climate activist, Martinez is also a hip-hop artist. In 2018, he released his first full-length hip-hop album, Break Free, which covers climate change and the marginalization of indigenous people, according to i-D. 

View this post on Instagram

The world has to fall apart to be more than what it is. . And I guess that’s what this is. The storms and the fires. The disappearing ice and rising tides. The people suffering. The monsters being put in power. An old broken world falling away. Making room for the vision my generation has of the world we’ll build. . It’s hard to believe things will get better when the lights burn this low. I struggle with that. We have to have hope in our power to push the scales in the right direction. Do what you can and a little more. Fight for your people and those that look nothing like you. Defend clean water. Protect your heart. Resist injustice. Take time to love yo momma. . Its never been easy. And the struggle will prolly never be. I’m tryin. Fire in the eyes of this young boy. Of a world burning and a generation on fire with passion. Thank you for having my back. Como familia. That’s how we’ll overcome 💧🌊 . Foto: @rickyrozay #breakfree

A post shared by Xiuhtezcatl (@xiuhtezcatl) on Oct 11, 2018 at 11:29am PDT

Since then, he launched the first-ever drag house for kids, which is currently under works, according to his website. On social media, he stands up against bullying and advocates for LGBTQ youth. His main message to his thousands of followers is "be yourself, always."

Change the Ref was founded by Manuel and Patricia Oliver, whose son Joaquin was killed during the Parkland school shooting. The nonprofit organization empowers young people to get involved in politics and help end gun violence.

@changetheref Back to School fashion show/protest to show how ridiculous our level of gun violence is with back to school fashions reflecting our culture. Never again. @gaysagainstgunsny Photos 1-4: @desmondisamazing Photos 5-10: @donnaaceto . . . #changetheref #altdrag #babydrag #beauty #boysinmakeup #brooklyndrag #clubkid #clubkids #drag #dragart #dragartist #dragkid #dragkids #draglife #dragqueen #dragqueer #dragsuperstar #influencer #klubkids #love #myartistcommunity #mua #nonbinary #nycdrag #punky #queerartist #queermodel . #desmondisamazing #beyourselfalways #amazies . booking: @pegmgmt

A post shared by Desmond is Amazing (@desmondisamazing) on Sep 12, 2018 at 5:07pm PDT

A post shared by March For Our Lives (@marchforourlives) on Apr 19, 2018 at 12:20pm PDT

Reid also launched Bamazing, an initiative to promote self-love and encourage girls to believe in themselves. She designed so-called "You Are" shirts that say "you=extraordinary" and "you= inspiring," along with other accolades. Celebrities, including Yara Shahidi (Black-ish) and Zendaya (The Greatest Showman), have been wearing the shirts. Sales from the tees benefit LadyLike Foundation, an organization that offers workshops and classes to help girls in underprivileged communities reach their full potential, and Array Alliance, an independent film festival founded by Ava DuVernay.

God please help me to keep dreaming of ways to make a positive impact on young girls. ✨I’m super excited to soon launch an initiative that I pray will make a difference in someone else’s life. Putting my words into action✨ Bamazing aims to empower young girls by helping them discover and nurture their inner light through the encouragement of positive declarations of self. A post shared by Storm Reid 💥💫 (@stormreid) on Sep 1, 2018 at 2:17pm PDT

In September, she hosted the #WeVoteNext Summit in Los Angeles. Celebrities like Lauren Jauregui and Laverne Cox, as well as activists David Hogg and Nadya Okamoto, of PERIOD, a nonprofit that provides menstrual supplies to people in need, attended to support the cause. — Yara shahidi (@YaraShahidi) March 8, 2018

In a Time essay, actress Josie Totah came out as a transgender female. The actress previously starred in Disney Channel's Jessie and Mindy Kaling's series Champions. On social media, she advocates for LGBTQ rights and other important causes. For example, she encouraged her followers to join the Trevor Project, which provides crisis and suicide prevention services for LGBTQ youth, in its fight to end conversion therapy. The Human Rights Campaign this year awarded Totah the HRC Visibility Award, which recognizes people who use their talent and platform to support LGBTQ people. 

View this post on Instagram

For so long I’ve been trying to hide who I was by pretending I’m someone I’m not. And I did it in fear. In fear that I wouldn’t be accepted or loved. I tried so hard to become a person that I knew I never was. But I’m realizing I can’t fake it forever. I know now more than ever I’m ready to take the step to becoming myself. I am Transgender and this is my story.

A post shared by josie (@josietotah) on Aug 20, 2018 at 10:01am PDT

Correction Dec. 24, 2018, 10:04 a.m. PST A previous version of this post incorrectly noted the name of the shirts Storm Reid has been selling to promote self-love. They are called "You Are" shirts not bamazing, which is the name of her initiative.
